Baek.text: I had a great time in today's lesson.

abc.text: I am so sad
The dusty smell coming from the carpet made me regret stepping on it.
I instantly backed away when I saw mold covering the walls.
The dusty smell coming from the carpet made me regret stepping on it.
The professor gave me too many assignments
The professor gave me too many assignments

It feels like the world outside has adopted the same gray filter that's been hanging over my mood all week. There's no specific tragedy to point to, just a persistent, low-level hum of melancholy that makes everything feel a little muted and insignificant. I find myself drifting through tasks without enthusiasm, and even things I usually look forward to—like reading a good book or listening to music—fail to spark any real joy. It's the kind of quiet sadness that doesn't demand attention, but simply absorbs the color out of the day. Maybe I'm just tired, or perhaps this is just one of those emotional troughs everyone cycles through. I keep reminding myself that feelings, like the weather, are temporary, yet the prospect of waiting for the sun to break through feels exhausting right now.

I tried to combat the slump earlier by going for a walk, hoping the fresh air and change of scenery would help, but it just ended up confirming my internal state. The streets seemed ordinary, the people rushed and preoccupied, and I felt utterly detached, like a silent observer in my own life. I spent the evening staring at the ceiling, thinking about all the things I should be doing versus what I actually felt capable of, which was nothing much at all. It’s frustrating to have a mind full of ambitions but a spirit too heavy to execute them. I suppose all I can do is acknowledge this feeling, not try to force a change, and hope that tomorrow brings a slightly lighter step. I’ll write down one small positive thing before I sleep, even if it's just the fact that I remembered to eat dinner.

I stopped breathing for a moment when a foul scent filled the elevator.
I backed away when I noticed a layer of dust thick enough to write on.
I have a lot of work to do
im too sleepy
i have no friend to play video game...
i'm too tired
i have no friends to play game

Today feels heavy, a kind of deep, aching sadness that settles in my bones. It’s not just one thing, but a culmination of small disappointments and the quiet realization that some things will never be the way they were. The rain outside mirrors the gray feeling in my chest; everything seems muted, colorless, and distant. I tried to shake it off, to focus on something positive, but the effort felt exhausting, and eventually, I just let the gloom take over. I wish I could fast-forward through this feeling, but I know I just have to sit with it until the light returns, however long that takes.

The morning started under a cloud of deep disappointment. I felt incredibly lonely, and a specific memory of a recent setback kept playing in my mind, making my chest ache. I even shed a few tears, convinced that nothing good would happen today. But later, as I was walking, a thought suddenly struck me: I have the power to change this moment. I decided to call an old friend I hadn't spoken to in months. Our conversation flowed so easily—full of laughter and shared memories—and it completely lifted my spirits. It was a simple connection, yet it reminded me that joy is often found in reaching out, and that even the darkest days can hold unexpected moments of beautiful light. I feel so much lighter now, ready for tomorrow.

Today was a dream come true! I finally received the acceptance letter for the art residency I've wanted for years. I was literally jumping around the apartment, screaming with pure, unadulterated joy. I felt like I was floating on air, completely invincible, and spent the entire afternoon texting everyone and planning the move. Later, as I settled down and looked out the window, I noticed something strange across the street: a light flickering rapidly in the top window of the old, abandoned house. It wasn't just blinking; it seemed frantic. I dismissed it at first, attributing it to the cold, but then I saw a shadow—tall, thin, and definitely not static—pass behind the glass. My heart instantly dropped from its peak of happiness into a pit of icy dread. The silence in my apartment suddenly felt deafening, and now I can't shake the chilling feeling that someone is watching.

“Where could it be?” Sophie asked herself. It had been more 
than ten years since she had last visited the area where she had 
grown up. The village had changed a lot over time. Uncertain, 
she awkwardly looked around at her surroundings. She walked 
the narrow streets of the village, unsure about which way to 
go. Suddenly, Sophie saw a familiar sight. “Yes, this must be 
it,” she thought. In front of her was a wall with flowers painted 
on it. Although the colors were now faded, the familiar shapes 
on the wall were the same ones she had painted with her father 
as a child. Sophie nodded, smiled brightly, and walked toward 
the gate. At last, she had finally found the house she had 
grown up in.

It was Valentine’s Day on Friday and Peter was certain that 
his wife, Amy, was going to love his surprise. Peter had spent 
a long time searching online for an event that would be a new 
way to spend time with Amy. He had finally found the perfect 
thing for her. She often told him that she liked to go to places 
she had never visited before, and he was absolutely sure that 
she would love going to the new, five-star restaurant downtown.
He smiled as he called the restaurant and asked for a reservation 
for Friday. Unfortunately, his smile quickly disappeared when 
he was told that the restaurant was fully reserved. “That’s too
bad,” he said quietly. “I thought that I had found the right 
place.”
